mn51:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ.
mn51:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
mn51:1.2.comm: Campā is modern Champapur near Bhagalpur in Bihar state, not far from West Bengal. It is near the eastern-most reach of the Buddha’s journeys. Campā was the capital of Aṅga, one of the sixteen “great nations” (mahājanapadā). It was a flourishing trade center, and became a sacred city for the Jains. | Gaggarā, an onomatopoeic reduplication (“gargle”), is the name of a number of rivers and whirlpools in Sanskrit (cp. the modern Ghaggar River in north-west India).

mn51:1.3.pli: Atha kho pesso ca hatthārohaputto kandarako ca paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā pesso hatthārohaputto bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn51:1.3.eng: Then Pessa the elephant driver’s son and Kandaraka the wanderer went to see the Buddha. When they had approached, Pessa bowed and sat down to one side.

mn51:1.4.pli: Kandarako pana paribbājako bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
mn51:1.4.eng: But the wanderer Kandaraka exchanged greetings with the Buddha and stood to one side.

mn51:1.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho kandarako paribbājako tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn51:1.5.eng: He looked around the mendicant Saṅgha, who were so very silent, and said to the Buddha:

mn51:2.2.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ bhotā gotamena sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito.
mn51:2.2.eng: How the mendicant Saṅgha has been led to practice properly by the worthy Gotama!

mn51:2.3.pli: Yepi te, bho gotama, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto etaparamaṃyeva sammā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṭipādesuṃ—
mn51:2.3.eng: The perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly at best do so

mn51:2.4.pli: seyyathāpi etarahi bhotā gotamena sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito.
mn51:2.4.eng: like the worthy Gotama does in the present.”
mn51:2.4.comm: Kandaraka’s status as a (non-Buddhist) wanderer does not preclude his faith in the Buddha.

mn51:2.5.pli: Yepi te, bho gotama, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto etaparamaṃyeva sammā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṭipādessanti—

mn51:2.6.pli: seyyathāpi etarahi bhotā gotamena sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito”ti.

mn51:3.1.eng: “That’s so true, Kandaraka! That’s so true!
mn51:3.1.comm: We do not hear anything about Kandaraka after this exchange.

mn51:3.2.pli: Yepi te, kandaraka, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto etaparamaṃyeva sammā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṭipādesuṃ—
mn51:3.2.eng: The perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly at best do so

mn51:3.3.pli: seyyathāpi etarahi mayā sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito.
mn51:3.3.eng: like I do in the present.

mn51:3.4.pli: Yepi te, kandaraka, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto etaparamaṃyeva sammā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṭipādessanti—

mn51:3.5.pli: seyyathāpi etarahi mayā sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito.

mn51:3.6.pli: Santi hi, kandaraka, bhikkhū imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā.
mn51:3.6.eng: For in this mendicant Saṅgha there are perfected mendicants, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment.

mn51:3.7.pli: Santi hi, kandaraka, bhikkhū imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe sekkhā santatasīlā santatavuttino nipakā nipakavuttino;
mn51:3.7.eng: And in this mendicant Saṅgha there are trainee mendicants who are consistently ethical, living consistently, alert, living alertly.

mn51:3.8.eng: They meditate with their minds firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

mn51:3.10.pli: Idha, kandaraka, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
mn51:3.10.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

mn51:3.11.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
mn51:3.11.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

mn51:3.12.pli: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
mn51:3.12.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

mn51:3.13.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassan”ti.
mn51:3.13.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.”

mn51:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, pesso hatthārohaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn51:4.1.eng: When he had spoken, Pessa said to the Buddha:

mn51:4.3.pli: Yāva supaññattā cime, bhante, bhagavatā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya.
mn51:4.3.eng: How well described by the Buddha are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation! They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.
mn51:4.3.comm: Yāva supaññatta is also at DN 18:22.3; it is a variation of the standard yāva subhāsita.

mn51:4.4.pli: Mayampi hi, bhante, gihī odātavasanā kālena kālaṃ imesu catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā viharāma.
mn51:4.4.eng: For we white-clothed laypeople also from time to time meditate with our minds well established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
mn51:4.4.comm: The Buddha sometimes taught devotional meditations such as the six recollections for lay people, but passages such as this show there was no fundamental difference between lay and monastic meditations.

mn51:4.5.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, kāye kāyānupassino viharāma ātāpino sampajānā satimanto, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
mn51:4.5.eng: We meditate observing an aspect of the body …

mn51:4.6.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassino viharāma ātāpino sampajānā satimanto, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;

mn51:4.7.pli: citte cittānupassino viharāma ātāpino sampajānā satimanto, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;

mn51:4.8.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassino viharāma ātāpino sampajānā satimanto, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
mn51:4.8.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

mn51:4.10.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhante, bhagavā evaṃ manussagahane evaṃ manussakasaṭe evaṃ manussasāṭheyye vattamāne sattānaṃ hitāhitaṃ jānāti.
mn51:4.10.eng: How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though humans continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky.

mn51:4.11.eng: For human beings are shady, sir,

mn51:4.13.eng: For I can drive an elephant in training,

mn51:4.14.pli: Yāvatakena antarena campaṃ gatāgataṃ karissati sabbāni tāni sāṭheyyāni kūṭeyyāni vaṅkeyyāni jimheyyāni pātukarissati.
mn51:4.14.eng: and while going back and forth in Campā it’ll try all the tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints that it can.

mn51:4.15.pli: Amhākaṃ pana, bhante, dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā aññathāva kāyena samudācaranti aññathāva vācāya aññathāva nesaṃ cittaṃ hoti.
mn51:4.15.eng: But my bondservants, servants, and workers behave one way by body, another by speech, and their minds another.

mn51:4.17.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhante, bhagavā evaṃ manussagahane evaṃ manussakasaṭe evaṃ manussasāṭheyye vattamāne sattānaṃ hitāhitaṃ jānāti.
mn51:4.17.eng: How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though humans continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky.

mn51:4.18.eng: For human beings are shady, sir,

mn51:5.1.eng: “That’s so true, Pessa! That’s so true!

mn51:5.4.pli: Cattārome, pessa, puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
mn51:5.4.eng: Pessa, these four individuals are found in the world.

mn51:5.6.pli: Idha, pessa, ekacco puggalo attantapo hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
mn51:5.6.eng: One individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

mn51:5.7.pli: idha pana, pessa, ekacco puggalo parantapo hoti paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
mn51:5.7.eng: One individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.

mn51:5.8.pli: idha pana, pessa, ekacco puggalo attantapo ca hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
mn51:5.8.eng: One individual mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

mn51:5.9.pli: idha pana, pessa, ekacco puggalo nevattantapo hoti nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn51:5.9.eng: One individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.

mn51:5.10.pli: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
mn51:5.10.eng: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.
mn51:5.10.comm: “With self become divine” (brahmabhūtena attanā) deliberately echoes Upaniṣadic language. Pali is sometimes said to lack reference to the cosmic Brahman (in neuter), having only the personal Brahmā (in masculine). The grammatical case of brahma- in the compound here is undetermined, yet no scholar of Sanskrit would hesitate to interpret the common phrase brahmabhūtātmā in the sense “self become one with the cosmic divinity Brahman”. Surely the Pali draws from the same sense, using it to describe Nibbāna.

mn51:5.11.pli: Imesaṃ, pessa, catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ katamo te puggalo cittaṃ ārādhetī”ti?
mn51:5.11.eng: Which one of these four individuals do you like the sound of?”

mn51:5.12.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bhante, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, ayaṃ me puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.
mn51:5.12.eng: “Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three individuals.

mn51:5.13.pli: Yopāyaṃ, bhante, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, ayampi me puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.

mn51:5.14.pli: Yopāyaṃ, bhante, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, ayampi me puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.

mn51:5.15.pli: Yo ca kho ayaṃ, bhante, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati—

mn51:5.16.eng: I only like the sound of the last individual, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”

mn51:6.1.pli: “Kasmā pana te, pessa, ime tayo puggalā cittaṃ nārādhentī”ti?
mn51:6.1.eng: “But why don’t you like the sound of those three individuals?”

mn51:6.2.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bhante, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānaṃ sukhakāmaṃ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṃ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
mn51:6.2.eng: “Sir, the individual who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain.

mn51:6.3.pli: iminā me ayaṃ puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.
mn51:6.3.eng: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.

mn51:6.4.pli: Yopāyaṃ, bhante, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so paraṃ sukhakāmaṃ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṃ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
mn51:6.4.eng: The individual who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain.

mn51:6.5.pli: iminā me ayaṃ puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.
mn51:6.5.eng: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.

mn51:6.6.pli: Yopāyaṃ, bhante, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṃ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṃ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
mn51:6.6.eng: The individual who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain.

mn51:6.7.pli: iminā me ayaṃ puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.
mn51:6.7.eng: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.

mn51:6.8.pli: Yo ca kho ayaṃ, bhante, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati;
mn51:6.8.eng: The individual who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain.

mn51:6.9.pli: so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṃ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṃ neva ātāpeti na paritāpeti—

mn51:6.10.pli: iminā me ayaṃ puggalo cittaṃ ārādheti.
mn51:6.10.eng: That’s why I like the sound of that individual.

mn51:6.11.pli: Handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bhante, gacchāma;
mn51:6.11.eng: Well, now, sir, I must go.

mn51:6.12.eng: I have many duties, and much to do.”

mn51:6.14.pli: Atha kho pesso hatthārohaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
mn51:6.14.eng: And then Pessa the elephant driver’s son approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
mn51:6.14.comm: Presumably Kandaraka left too. This sutta has an odd structure, as the bulk of the teaching occurs after the protagonists leave. This has the ring of a genuinely random encounter.

mn51:7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkante pesse hatthārohaputte bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn51:7.1.eng: Then, not long after he had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

mn51:7.2.eng: “Mendicants, Pessa the elephant driver’s son is astute.

mn51:7.4.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, pesso hatthārohaputto muhuttaṃ nisīdeyya yāvassāhaṃ ime cattāro puggale vitthārena vibhajissāmi, mahatā atthena saṃyutto abhavissa.
mn51:7.4.eng: If he had sat here an hour so that I could have analyzed these four individuals in detail, he would have greatly benefited.

mn51:7.5.pli: Api ca, bhikkhave, ettāvatāpi pesso hatthārohaputto mahatā atthena saṃyutto”ti.
mn51:7.5.eng: Still, even with this much he has already greatly benefited.”

mn51:7.6.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

mn51:7.7.pli: yaṃ bhagavā ime cattāro puggale vitthārena vibhajeyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
mn51:7.7.eng: May the Buddha analyze these four individuals in detail. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

mn51:7.8.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn51:7.8.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn51:7.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn51:8.1.pli: “Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo acelako hoti muttācāro hatthāpalekhano naehibhaddantiko natiṭṭhabhaddantiko; nābhihaṭaṃ na uddissakataṃ na nimantanaṃ sādiyati;
mn51:8.1.eng: “And what individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves? It’s when an individual goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared for them, or an invitation for a meal.
mn51:8.1.comm: For these practices, which were pursued by the Buddha before his awakening, see notes at MN 12:45.1.

mn51:8.2.pli: so na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti na eḷakamantaraṃ na daṇḍamantaraṃ na musalamantaraṃ na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ na gabbhiniyā na pāyamānāya na purisantaragatāya na saṅkittīsu na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī; na macchaṃ na maṃsaṃ na suraṃ na merayaṃ na thusodakaṃ pivati.
mn51:8.2.eng: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.

mn51:8.3.pli: So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko …pe… sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko;
mn51:8.3.eng: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.

mn51:8.4.pli: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti …pe… sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti;
mn51:8.4.eng: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.

mn51:8.5.pli: ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti …pe… sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti—iti evarūpaṃ aḍḍhamāsikaṃ pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
mn51:8.5.eng: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.

mn51:8.6.pli: So sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti; vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
mn51:8.6.eng: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

mn51:8.7.pli: So sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṃsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhampi dhāreti;
mn51:8.7.eng: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.

mn51:8.8.eng: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.

mn51:8.9.eng: They constantly stand, turning down seats.

mn51:8.10.eng: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.

mn51:8.11.eng: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.

mn51:8.12.eng: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.

mn51:8.13.pli: iti evarūpaṃ anekavihitaṃ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
mn51:8.13.eng: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.

mn51:8.14.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn51:8.14.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

mn51:9.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
mn51:9.1.eng: And what individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?

mn51:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo orabbhiko hoti sūkariko sākuṇiko māgaviko luddo macchaghātako coro coraghātako goghātako bandhanāgāriko, ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā.
mn51:9.2.eng: It’s when an individual is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, or poultry, a hunter or trapper, a fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher, a jailer, or someone with some other kind of cruel livelihood.

mn51:9.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn51:9.3.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

mn51:10.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
mn51:10.1.eng: And what individual mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?

mn51:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo rājā vā hoti khattiyo muddhāvasitto brāhmaṇo vā mahāsālo.
mn51:10.2.eng: It’s when an individual is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
mn51:10.2.comm: The same vivid description of ritual is found at MN 94:12.2 and AN 4.198:6.2. | The passage features many details close to the sacrifice as described in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, especially chapter 3, to which I refer below. Of course the attitude is the exact opposite.

mn51:10.3.pli: So puratthimena nagarassa navaṃ santhāgāraṃ kārāpetvā kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kharājinaṃ nivāsetvā sappitelena kāyaṃ abbhañjitvā magavisāṇena piṭṭhiṃ kaṇḍuvamāno navaṃ santhāgāraṃ pavisati saddhiṃ mahesiyā brāhmaṇena ca purohitena.
mn51:10.3.eng: He has a new ceremonial hall built to the east of the citadel. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the hall with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.
mn51:10.3.comm: Santhāgāra is normally a hall to gather for business, a “town hall”. Here, however, the term draws on the idiom yajñasya saṁsthā, (“completion/establishment of the sacrifice”), which is so common the term “sacrifice” may be left out as implied (eg. 13.2.4.2). Thus it is “a building for completing the sacrifice” (commentary: yaññasāla). | The hall for sacrifice, referred to simply as śālā (3.1.1), is oriented to the east, for “the east is the quarter of the gods” (3.1.1.6). | Shaving hair and beard before the sacrifice is described in detail (3.1.2). | The anointing is with navanīta (“fresh butter”, 3.1.3.7 ff.). | The sacrificer wears clean linen (3.1.2.13), but sits on antelope hide (3.2.1.1), scratching himself with the horn (3.2.1.31; cf. Rig Veda 7.18.7). | The wife’s fertility cleanses and heals (3.5.3.13, 3.8.2). A king enters the “fire chamber” (agnyāgāra) with four wives (13.4.1.8).

mn51:10.4.pli: So tattha anantarahitāya bhūmiyā haritupalittāya seyyaṃ kappeti.
mn51:10.4.eng: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.
mn51:10.4.comm: He lies down to sleep in the evening (3.2.2.22), with his wives, but refraining from sex (13.4.1.9). | The spreading of grass is a regular feature of Vedic ritual (eg. 3.6.3.14).

mn51:10.5.pli: Ekissāya gāviyā sarūpavacchāya yaṃ ekasmiṃ thane khīraṃ hoti tena rājā yāpeti, yaṃ dutiyasmiṃ thane khīraṃ hoti tena mahesī yāpeti, yaṃ tatiyasmiṃ thane khīraṃ hoti tena brāhmaṇo purohito yāpeti, yaṃ catutthasmiṃ thane khīraṃ hoti tena aggiṃ juhati, avasesena vacchako yāpeti.
mn51:10.5.eng: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the leftovers.
mn51:10.5.comm: After shaving, the sacrificer consumes milk (3.1.2.1) from all four teats or fewer (9.5.1.6), breaking his fast with milk cooked with rice or barley (3.2.2.10, 14). | Milk is drawn from specific teats (3.4.4.26, 9.5.1; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.8.1). | Milk is cooked from a white cow with white calf (5.3.2.1), or in another rite from a black cow with white calf (9.2.3.30).

mn51:10.7.pli: ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā assā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā rukkhā chijjantu yūpatthāya, ettakā dabbhā lūyantu barihisatthāyā’ti.
mn51:10.7.eng: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’
mn51:10.7.comm: The slaughter of animal victims is described in detail (3.7.3). | The sacrificer ought not use the worldly term “slaughter” (Pali haññantu = Sanskrit jahi), rather “make them agree”, “persuade” (saṁjñapaya, 3.8.1.15) so they look forward to being sacrificed (3.7.3.4). | Trees are felled to make the stake (yūpa) to which the animals are tied, while grass (darbha) is strewn on the altar (3.6.4).

mn51:10.8.pli: Yepissa te honti dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karonti.
mn51:10.8.eng: His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.

mn51:10.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn51:10.9.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

mn51:11.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati?
mn51:11.1.eng: And what individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, but lives without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine?

mn51:12.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā.
mn51:12.1.eng: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.

mn51:12.2.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
mn51:12.2.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

mn51:12.3.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
mn51:12.3.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

mn51:13.1.pli: Taṃ dhammaṃ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto.
mn51:13.1.eng: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.

mn51:13.2.pli: So taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati.
mn51:13.2.eng: They gain faith in the Realized One

mn51:13.3.pli: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn51:13.4.eng: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.

mn51:13.5.pli: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
mn51:13.5.eng: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

mn51:13.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn51:13.6.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn51:13.7.pli: So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya, mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya, appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya, mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā, kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mn51:13.7.eng: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn51:14.1.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṃ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
mn51:14.1.eng: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.

mn51:14.2.pli: Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
mn51:14.2.eng: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.

mn51:14.3.pli: Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
mn51:14.3.eng: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.

mn51:14.4.pli: Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassa.
mn51:14.4.eng: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.

mn51:14.5.pli: Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya—iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
mn51:14.5.eng: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

mn51:14.6.pli: Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
mn51:14.6.eng: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

mn51:14.7.pli: Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ.
mn51:14.7.eng: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

mn51:14.8.eng: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.

mn51:14.9.eng: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

mn51:14.10.eng: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .

mn51:14.11.eng: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

mn51:14.12.eng: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.

mn51:14.13.eng: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,

mn51:14.22.eng: They refrain from running errands and messages;

mn51:14.26.eng: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

mn51:15.1.pli: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
mn51:15.1.eng: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

mn51:15.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti, sapattabhārova ḍeti;
mn51:15.2.eng: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.

mn51:15.3.pli: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
mn51:15.3.eng: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

mn51:15.4.pli: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
mn51:15.4.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

mn51:16.1.pli: So cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
mn51:16.1.eng: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

mn51:16.2.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
mn51:16.2.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

mn51:16.3.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

mn51:16.4.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

mn51:16.5.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

mn51:16.6.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

mn51:16.7.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
mn51:16.7.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

mn51:16.8.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
mn51:16.8.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

mn51:16.9.pli: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ abyāsekasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
mn51:16.9.eng: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.

mn51:17.1.pli: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
mn51:17.1.eng: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

mn51:18.1.pli: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
mn51:18.1.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,

mn51:18.2.pli: vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.
mn51:18.2.eng: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

mn51:19.1.pli: So pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
mn51:19.1.eng: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.

mn51:19.2.pli: So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti,
mn51:19.2.eng: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.

mn51:19.3.pli: byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti;
mn51:19.3.eng: Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will and malevolence.

mn51:19.4.pli: thinamiddhaṃ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti;
mn51:19.4.eng: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.

mn51:19.5.pli: uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti;
mn51:19.5.eng: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.

mn51:19.6.pli: vicikicchaṃ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn51:19.6.eng: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

mn51:20.1.pli: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,
mn51:20.1.eng: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

mn51:20.2.pli: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
mn51:20.2.eng: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn51:21.1.pli: vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
mn51:21.1.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn51:22.1.pli: pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
mn51:22.1.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn51:23.1.pli: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn51:23.1.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn51:24.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn51:24.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.

mn51:24.2.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
mn51:24.2.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

mn51:25.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn51:25.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

mn51:25.2.pli: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
mn51:25.2.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

mn51:26.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn51:26.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

mn51:26.2.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn51:26.2.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

mn51:27.1.pli: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṃ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṃ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn51:27.1.eng: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

mn51:27.2.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati.
mn51:27.2.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

mn51:27.3.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn51:27.4.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn51:27.4.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn51:28.1.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn51:28.1.eng: This is called an individual who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.

mn51:28.2.pli: So attantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharatī”ti.
mn51:28.2.eng: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”

mn51:28.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn51:28.4.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn51:28.4.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
